value: File:Yellow Springs in the Glen Helen Nature Preserve.jpg
Yellow Springs in the Glen Helen Nature Preserve

The Village of Yellow Springs was founded in 1825. It was named for a natural spring rich in iron ore located in

. Legend has it that if you drink from the spring you will always return.

In the conservative stronghold of Southwest Ohio not far from a major air force base, Yellow Springs has the reputation for being an island of left-wing activism supported by its small liberal arts school, Antioch College.  Some locals go as far as to call it the

of Ohio.  When school is in session people watching is an interesting event given the personalities this college attracts.

The Village offers some of the best dining in the Dayton area, along with several artisan groups and a downtown bustling with side-walk shops. All of this lies a short distance from  Ohio's best natural area, including

and Glen Helen. 

The Village can get quite congested on warm-weathered weekends, but nearly all of its attractions are open during weekdays, which offer less in the way of crowds. As of the 2000 census the population was 3,761.
Yellow Springs is on route 68, just 7 1/2 miles south of route I-70. It is approximately a half hour drive from
, and a one hour drive from

value: http://www.daytonairport.com/ James M. Cox Dayton International Airport

. Rental cars are available at both locations.
The Greyhound bus stops in nearby
Yellow Springs is accessible by the excellent system of bicycle trails thanks to Ohio's Rails to Trails program. A 10 mile ride south on the trail will lead to
. Parking and access to the trail, are available at the

Yellow Springs is 1.9 square miles. The downtown area is easily walkable. It is relatively flat and a great town to get around by foot or on a bike. Bike rentals are available at the Village Cyclery 110 Dayton St. +1 937 767-9330. If you want to visit any of the attractions outside of the town you will need a car. Yellow Springs has no public transportation system.
You will find something enjoyable for the whole family.

value: . Intimate theater showing a savvy mix of mainstream and independent films.

content=Is located one mile north of Yellow Springs. Young's offers miniature golf, batting cages, a driving range and a petting zoo. The Golden Jersey Inn serves "home-style country cooked meals", handmade ice cream and gelato.
name=National Museum of the United States Air Force

content=Located in nearby Fairborn, the museum boasts 400 aerospace vehicles, as well as an abundance of historical items. Admission to the museum is free, however there is a fee for the Imax theater.

content=Built in 1802 is one of the largest water powered grist mills. Here you can tour the mill, visit the 1940's Gas Station Museum and even cross the Little Miami River on a ninety foot covered bridge.

There are lots of outdoor activities in and around Yellow Springs.

dedicated to the rehabilitation of birds of prey. You can see some of the permanently disabled birds in outdoor cages, and there are flight cages for birds who are recovering.
content=Is a two hundred and sixty eight acre State Nature Preserve adjoining the nearby Village of Clifton. It has many geological and botanical features. Great for hiking.
content=Is located just a few minutes outside Yellow Springs and is adjacent to Clifton Gorge. The park offers camping, fishing, hunting, canoeing, mountain biking, rock climbing and repelling.
content=Is a linear park with 72 paved miles for biking, jogging, roller blading, or walking.

The Yellow Springs Street fair happens twice a year. On the second Saturdays of June and October the  main streets in town are closed for vendors, live music and international cuisine.
Yellow Springs has a plethora of independent shops and artisans.

value: content=The largest selection of Herbs, Spices, Teas and Essential Oils in the area.

Yellow Springs offers many dining options with something to please every palate.

value: content=107. Regional chain serving pizza, salads, pasta, calzones and wings. Delivery available.
name=Corner Cone Dairy Bar and Grill

name=Emporium Wines and the Underdog Cafe

content=Freshly made fruit smoothies. Bagels and cream cheese. Wine and beer making supplies.
content=Live music in the evenings. A great selection of sandwiches, wraps and Mexican entrees. Beer, wine and spirits

content=Fine dining with an extensive wine list, on premises bakery and homemade desserts, espresso and mixed drinks. Menu changes monthly. Special events include the Annual Garlic Dinner.

content=Eco*Mental is a one stop shop for all things promoting an eco-friendly, sustainable lifestyle! Great organic lollipops!
content=This hometown favorite dive draws an eclectic crowd. Pool table.
content=Features live music, domestic and imported beers on tap and good bar food.
Over forty beers and wines to choose from. Enjoy one in front of the fireplace, in the solarium or out on the deck.
